title: Members
text:
Meet all currently members of lab25














Member & Interests


Contact









Jocelyn Garc√≠aCurrently, I am working on a computational model aimed at modeling the process of acquiring new concepts, its impact on the transformation of prior concepts, and the implications it has on the specialization of schemata. The intention is to use Artificial Neural Networks, decision-making models, and Bayesian models.Topics of interestArtificial Neural Networks, Computer Modelling, Categorization, Decision Making Process & Learning Models.


Contact ‚úâ









Alicia Mu√±izComing soon‚Ä¶Topics of interestComputational Neuroscience, Computational Psychiatry & Artificial Intelligence.


Contact ‚úâ









Christian BadilloMember of research projects at the Adaptive Behavior Laboratory, with expertise in psychology, programming, and statistics. Currently focused on applications of statistical and causal methods to study adaptative behavior.Topics of interestReinforcement Learning, Neuroscience, Bayesian Statistics, Causality & Applied Statistics.


Contact ‚úâ









Hugo CardenasMember of research projects at the Adaptive Behavior Laboratory, with expertise in psychology, programming, and statistics. Currently focused on research, coding, and development of learning models and agent-based models applied to decision making, strategic interactions and cognition.Topics of interestReinforcement Learning, Neuroscience, Learning models, Game Theory, Behavioral Economics, Bayesian Statistics, Cognition & Neural Networks.


Contact ‚úâ









Miguel TorresComing soon‚Ä¶Topics of interestReinforcement Learning, Artificial Intelligence, Learning models, Game Theory, Planning.


Contact ‚úâ









Israel VaronaComing soon‚Ä¶Topics of interestDecision Making


Contact ‚úâ









Mayari Holgu√≠nComing soon‚Ä¶Topics of interestBehavioral Economics, Game theory & Decision Making


Contact ‚úâ









Rodrigo AlvarezCurrently working on a behavioral intervention and field experiment that seeks to evaluate the potential of different nudging policies to improve the recycling behaviors of university students at UNAM‚Äôs Psychology Department.Topics of interestEnvironmental Public Policy, Behavioral Modelling, Nudging & Ecological Economics.


Contact ‚úâ









Eunice M√©ndezHello :) I‚Äôm Eunice. My research focuses on the study of decision-making in human agents within strategic interaction environments, with an emphasis on the evolution of their strategies in repeated interactions. I aim for the experimental data not only to contribute to theoretical development but also to have practical applications in solving real-world problems, such as cooperation in competitive environments..Topics of interestGame Theory, Behavioral Economics & Evolutionary Biology


Contact ‚úâ









Amelie ArroyoI am a Psychology student with a strong interest in the intersection of behavioral science and technology. My focus is on decision-making from a computational perspective, studying how algorithms explain behavior in both biological and artificial agents. Additionally, I am passionate about integrating adaptive behavior algorithms into robots, exploring how these systems can replicate and learn behavioral dynamics. I investigate the exploration-exploitation trade-off and its application in virtual environments to better understand decision-making in adaptive systems. As a member of the IEEE Computer Society, I contribute to electronics and programming projects, advancing computing applications within the field.Topics of interestReinforcement Learning, Neural Networks, Decision Making, Computational Models of Behavior, Robotics & Behavior Dynamics.


Contact ‚úâ









Mar√≠a Rodr√≠guezPsychology student with experience in interdisciplinary projects and training in brain bioenergetics, blue economy, and degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer‚Äôs, multiple sclerosis, and type 2 diabetes. Participant in the CEMIE-Oc√©ano Engineering Project and developer of an educational game on blue economy.Topics of interestBehavioral Economics, Clinical Research, Choice Modelling & Neural Networks.


Contact ‚úâ

title: lab25
text:
About Us!


Lab25, located within the Faculty of Psychology at the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) in Mexico City, investigates the principles by which organisms acquire knowledge about their environment‚Äôs structure and how this knowledge guides their actions within it.
We study the solutions, mechanisms, and principles of behavior that enable agents, both biological and artificial, to solve the problem of adaptation to the statistical properties that describe the availability of biologically important events for an organism. The laboratory‚Äôs primary areas of investigation include Reinforcement Learning, decision-making processes under conditions of temporal constraints and risk, temporal processing, Game Theory, Categorization, and Bayesian Modeling.







May, 2023 Guest Professor Peter Killeen

‚úåÔ∏èAbout Us!


Lab25 is an innovative and highly motivated research center on Cognitive and Behavioral Science, located in the Faculty of Psychology from the National Autonomous University of M√©xico, in Mexico City. Our main goal is to contribute to a better understanding of humans and non-human organisms‚Äô behaviour as an adaptative response to the structure of the envireonment they live in. More specifically, we focus on conducting research in terms of: Reinforcement Learning Intertemporal choice Risky choice Perceptual decission making Timing Game Theory Categorization Bayesian modeling







May, 2023 Guest Professor Peter Killeen

title: Dr.¬†Arturo Bouzas
text:
Education
Obtained his B.A in Psychology at UNAM in 1967. He has an M.S in clinical Psychology from State University of New York at Stony Brook, where he worked in Howard Rachlin‚Äôs laboratory, withn Leonard Green and Gene Heyman. During that time, his interest shifted from the clinical to the experimental area. He obteinend his PhD in Experimental Psychology from Harvard University in 1976, for his work contingencies in instrumental behavior.
After completing his PhD, his interest in the biological processes of behaviour directed him to a post doctoral position in animal behaviour at Toronto University (1977-1978) where he stayed as associate researcher until 1980.
Upon returning to Mexico, he incorporated as a faculty member at the School of Psychology at UNAM, which he directed from 1997 to 2001. Afterwards, he was a visiting professor at the University of California, San Diego.
He is currently a full-time tenured professor, part of the National System of Researchers (second level) and currently holds the Ezequiel A. Chavez special chair.
